newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: CRICKET-FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD TEST PLAYER RAZA STARTS IN STYLE.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD TEST PLAYER RAZA STARTS IN STYLE.

text.p: Hasan Raza, at 14
years and 227 days easily the youngest to play test cricket,
began in sparkling style with four boundaries to ensure Pakistan
remained well on top of Zimbabwe on the opening day of the
second test on Thursday.
Raza shared in an unbroken 47-run fourth wicket partnership
with opener Saeed Anwar in the closing session to make sure
Pakistan did not waste the earlier fast bowling efforts of
captain Wasim Akram who took six wickets as Zimbabwe were
dismissed for 133.
Pakistan also began their first innings inauspiciously,
losing their first two wickets with only 10 on the board and
their third when they reached 67.
Raza entered to loud cheers from the small crowd and
apparantly unfazed by the occasion, and opened his account with
an exquiste late cut off leg-spinner Paul Strang.
By the close, Raza was 20 not out and Anwar unbeaten on 69
as Pakistan reached 114 for three, only 19 behind Zimbabwe.
Anwar, dropped at 49 and 51, brought up his 12th half
century in his 19th test in 88 minutes off 59 balls with nine
fours. He has so far struck 13 fours after 130 minutes at the
crease.
Raza beat the previous record for the youngest test player,
held by current Pakistan team manager Mushtaq Muhammad who made
his debut at the age of 15 years and 124 days against West
Indies in Lahore in 1958-59.
Zimbabwe would hardly have objected to Raza gaining all the
attention as they collapsed miserably after winning the toss and
opting to bat first on a lively grass-top pitch at Faisalabad's
Iqbal Stadium.
Their plight would have much worse but for a fighting 61 by
left-hander Andy Flower. He was last out after batting for 174
minutes and hit seven fours from 143 balls.
Openers Grant Flower (15) and Mark Dekker (19) were the only
other batsmen to reach double figures.
Zimbabwe, 88 for five at luch, continued to decline in the
afternoon session, losing the last five wickets for just 45 runs
to be all out on the stroke of tea.
Akram finished with six for 48, his best figures against the
visitors, surpassing his five for 43 at Bulawayo in 1994-95. It
was Zimbabwe's lowest total by one run on Pakistani soil.
It continued an amazing series for the Pakistan captain who
made 257 in the drawn first test and shared in a world record
eighth wicket stand of 313.
